segment.source: Prepare your Windows desktop application (like Win32, WPF, and Windows Forms) for conversion to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app by using the Desktop Conversion extensions.
segment.target: Prepare your Windows desktop application (like Win32, WPF, and Windows Forms) for conversion to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app by using the Desktop Conversion extensions.

segment.source: Convert your desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app
segment.target: Convert your desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app

segment.source: Convert your desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app
segment.target: Convert your desktop application to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app

segment.source: Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.
segment.target: Some information relates to pre-released product which may be substantially modified before it's commercially released.

segment.source: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.
segment.target: Microsoft makes no warranties, express or implied, with respect to the information provided here.

segment.source: Prepare your Windows desktop application (like Win32, WPF, and Windows Forms) for conversion to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app by using the Desktop Conversion extensions.
segment.target: Prepare your Windows desktop application (like Win32, WPF, and Windows Forms) for conversion to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app by using the Desktop Conversion extensions.

segment.source: Benefits of converting your application to UWP
segment.target: Benefits of converting your application to UWP

segment.source: UWP using Desktop Conversion extensions is a bridge that enables you to convert your classic desktop application (like Win32, Windows Forms, and WPF) or game to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app or game.
segment.target: UWP using Desktop Conversion extensions is a bridge that enables you to convert your classic desktop application (like Win32, Windows Forms, and WPF) or game to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app or game.

segment.source: For more info, see Guide to UWP apps.
segment.target: For more info, see Guide to UWP apps.

segment.source: After conversion, your classic desktop app is packaged, serviced, and deployed in the form of a UWP app package (an .appx or an .appxbundle) targeting Windows 10 Desktop.
segment.target: After conversion, your classic desktop app is packaged, serviced, and deployed in the form of a UWP app package (an .appx or an .appxbundle) targeting Windows 10 Desktop.

segment.source: There are two parts to the technology that enables desktop apps to be converted to UWP packages.
segment.target: There are two parts to the technology that enables desktop apps to be converted to UWP packages.

segment.source: The first is the Desktop App Converter, which takes your existing binaries and repackages them as a UWP package.
segment.target: The first is the Desktop App Converter, which takes your existing binaries and repackages them as a UWP package.

segment.source: Your code is still the same, it's just packaged differently.
segment.target: Your code is still the same, it's just packaged differently.

segment.source: The second piece comprises runtime technologies in the Windows Anniversary update that enable a UWP package to have executables that run as full trust instead of in an app container.
segment.target: The second piece comprises runtime technologies in the Windows Anniversary update that enable a UWP package to have executables that run as full trust instead of in an app container.

segment.source: This technology also gives a converted app a package identity, which is required to use some UWP APIs.
segment.target: This technology also gives a converted app a package identity, which is required to use some UWP APIs.

segment.source: Here are some of the benefits of converting your classic desktop app.
segment.target: Here are some of the benefits of converting your classic desktop app.

segment.source: Your app's installation experience is much smoother for your customers.
segment.target: Your app's installation experience is much smoother for your customers.

segment.source: You can deploy it to computers using sideloading (see Sideload LOB apps in Windows 10), and it leaves no trace behind after being uninstalled.
segment.target: You can deploy it to computers using sideloading (see Sideload LOB apps in Windows 10), and it leaves no trace behind after being uninstalled.

segment.source: Longer term, you'll also be able to publish your app to the Windows Store.
segment.target: Longer term, you'll also be able to publish your app to the Windows Store.

segment.source: Because your converted app has package identity, you can call more UWP APIs, even from the full-trust partition, than you could before.
segment.target: Because your converted app has package identity, you can call more UWP APIs, even from the full-trust partition, than you could before.

segment.source: At your own pace, you can add UWP features to your app's package, like a XAML user-interface, live tile updates, UWP background tasks, app services, and many more.
segment.target: At your own pace, you can add UWP features to your app's package, like a XAML user-interface, live tile updates, UWP background tasks, app services, and many more.

segment.source: All of the functionality available to any other UWP app is available to your app.
segment.target: All of the functionality available to any other UWP app is available to your app.

segment.source: If you choose to move all of your app's functionality out of the full-trust partition of the app and into the app container partition, then your app will be able to run on any Windows 10 device.
segment.target: If you choose to move all of your app's functionality out of the full-trust partition of the app and into the app container partition, then your app will be able to run on any Windows 10 device.

segment.source: As a UWP app, your app is able to do the things it could do as a classic desktop app.
segment.target: As a UWP app, your app is able to do the things it could do as a classic desktop app.

segment.source: It interacts with a virtualized view of the registry and file system that's indistinguishable from the actual registry and file system.
segment.target: It interacts with a virtualized view of the registry and file system that's indistinguishable from the actual registry and file system.

segment.source: Your app can participate in the Windows Store's built-in licensing and automatic update facilities.
segment.target: Your app can participate in the Windows Store's built-in licensing and automatic update facilities.

segment.source: Automatic update is a highly reliable and efficient mechanism, because only the changed parts of files are downloaded.
segment.target: Automatic update is a highly reliable and efficient mechanism, because only the changed parts of files are downloaded.

segment.source: Preparing your desktop app for conversion to UWP
segment.target: Preparing your desktop app for conversion to UWP

segment.source: You may not need to do much to get your app ready for the conversion process.
segment.target: You may not need to do much to get your app ready for the conversion process.

segment.source: Remember that the Windows Store handles licensing and automatic updating for you, so you can remove those features from your codebase.
segment.target: Remember that the Windows Store handles licensing and automatic updating for you, so you can remove those features from your codebase.

segment.source: If any of these situations applies to your application, you need to address this issue before conversion.
segment.target: If any of these situations applies to your application, you need to address this issue before conversion.

segment.source: Your app uses a version of .NET earlier than 4.6.1.
segment.target: Your app uses a version of .NET earlier than 4.6.1.

segment.source: Only .NET 4.6.1 is supported.
segment.target: Only .NET 4.6.1 is supported.

segment.source: You must retarget your app to .NET 4.6.1 before converting.
segment.target: You must retarget your app to .NET 4.6.1 before converting.

segment.source: Your app always runs with elevated security privileges.
segment.target: Your app always runs with elevated security privileges.

segment.source: Your app needs to work while running as the interactive user.
segment.target: Your app needs to work while running as the interactive user.

segment.source: Users who install your app from the Windows Store may not be system administrators, so requiring your app to run elevated means that it won't run correctly for standard users.
segment.target: Users who install your app from the Windows Store may not be system administrators, so requiring your app to run elevated means that it won't run correctly for standard users.

segment.source: Your app requires a kernel-mode driver or a Windows service.
segment.target: Your app requires a kernel-mode driver or a Windows service.

segment.source: The bridge is suitable for an app, but it does not support a kernel-mode driver or a Windows service that needs to run under a system account.
segment.target: The bridge is suitable for an app, but it does not support a kernel-mode driver or a Windows service that needs to run under a system account.

segment.source: Instead of a Windows service, use a background task.
segment.target: Instead of a Windows service, use a background task.

segment.source: Your app's modules are loaded in-process to processes that are not in your AppX package.
segment.target: Your app's modules are loaded in-process to processes that are not in your AppX package.

segment.source: This isn't permitted, which means that in-process extensions, like shell extensions, aren't supported.
segment.target: This isn't permitted, which means that in-process extensions, like shell extensions, aren't supported.

segment.source: But if you have two apps in the same package, you can do inter-process communication between them.
segment.target: But if you have two apps in the same package, you can do inter-process communication between them.

segment.source: Your app uses a custom Application User Model ID (AUMID).
segment.target: Your app uses a custom Application User Model ID (AUMID).

segment.source: If your process calls SetCurrentProcessExplicitAppUserModelID to set its own AUMID, then it may only use the AUMID generated for it by the app model environment/AppX package.
segment.target: If your process calls SetCurrentProcessExplicitAppUserModelID to set its own AUMID, then it may only use the AUMID generated for it by the app model environment/AppX package.

segment.source: You can't define custom AUMIDs.
segment.target: You can't define custom AUMIDs.

segment.source: Your app modifies the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE (HKLM) registry hive.
segment.target: Your app modifies the HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE (HKLM) registry hive.

segment.source: Any attempt by your app to create an HKLM key, or to open one for modification, will result in an access-denied failure.
segment.target: Any attempt by your app to create an HKLM key, or to open one for modification, will result in an access-denied failure.

segment.source: Remember that your app has its own private virtualized view of the registry, so the notion of a user- and machine-wide registry hive (which is what HKLM is) does not apply.
segment.target: Remember that your app has its own private virtualized view of the registry, so the notion of a user- and machine-wide registry hive (which is what HKLM is) does not apply.

segment.source: You will need to find another way of achieving what you were using HKLM for, like writing to HKEY_CURRENT_USER (HKCU) instead.
segment.target: You will need to find another way of achieving what you were using HKLM for, like writing to HKEY_CURRENT_USER (HKCU) instead.

segment.source: Your app uses a ddeexec registry subkey as a means of launching another app.
segment.target: Your app uses a ddeexec registry subkey as a means of launching another app.

segment.source: Instead, use one of the DelegateExecute verb handlers as configured by the various Activatable* extensions in your app package manifest.
segment.target: Instead, use one of the DelegateExecute verb handlers as configured by the various Activatable* extensions in your app package manifest.

segment.source: Your app writes to the AppData folder with the intention of sharing data with another app.
segment.target: Your app writes to the AppData folder with the intention of sharing data with another app.

segment.source: After conversion, AppData is redirected to the local app data store, which is a private store for each UWP app.
segment.target: After conversion, AppData is redirected to the local app data store, which is a private store for each UWP app.

segment.source: Use a different means of inter-process data sharing.
segment.target: Use a different means of inter-process data sharing.

segment.source: For more info, see Store and retrieve settings and other app data.
segment.target: For more info, see Store and retrieve settings and other app data.

segment.source: Your app writes to the install directory for your app.
segment.target: Your app writes to the install directory for your app.

segment.source: For example, your app writes to a log file that you put in the same directory as your exe.
segment.target: For example, your app writes to a log file that you put in the same directory as your exe.

segment.source: This isn't supported, so you'll need to find another location, like the local app data store.
segment.target: This isn't supported, so you'll need to find another location, like the local app data store.

segment.source: Your app installation requires user interaction.
segment.target: Your app installation requires user interaction.

segment.source: Your app installer must be able to run silently, and it must install all of its prerequisites that aren't on by default on a clean OS image.
segment.target: Your app installer must be able to run silently, and it must install all of its prerequisites that aren't on by default on a clean OS image.

segment.source: Your app uses the Current Working Directory.
segment.target: Your app uses the Current Working Directory.

segment.source: At runtime, your converted app won't get the same Working Directory that you previously specified in your desktop .LNK shortcut.
segment.target: At runtime, your converted app won't get the same Working Directory that you previously specified in your desktop .LNK shortcut.

segment.source: You need to change your CWD at runtime if having the correct directory is important for your app to function correctly.
segment.target: You need to change your CWD at runtime if having the correct directory is important for your app to function correctly.

segment.source: Your app requires UIAccess.
segment.target: Your app requires UIAccess.

segment.source: If your application specifies in the element of the UAC manifest, conversion to UWP isn't supported currently.
segment.target: If your application specifies in the element of the UAC manifest, conversion to UWP isn't supported currently.

segment.source: For more info, see UI Automation Security Overview.
segment.target: For more info, see UI Automation Security Overview.

segment.source: Your app exposes COM objects or GAC assemblies for use by other processes.
segment.target: Your app exposes COM objects or GAC assemblies for use by other processes.

segment.source: In the current release, your app cannot expose COM objects or GAC assemblies for use by processes originating from executables external to your AppX package.
segment.target: In the current release, your app cannot expose COM objects or GAC assemblies for use by processes originating from executables external to your AppX package.

segment.source: Processes from within the package can register and use COM objects and GAC assemblies as normal, but they will not be visible externally.
segment.target: Processes from within the package can register and use COM objects and GAC assemblies as normal, but they will not be visible externally.

segment.source: This means interop scenarios like OLE will not function if invoked by external processes.
segment.target: This means interop scenarios like OLE will not function if invoked by external processes.

segment.source: Your app is linking C runtime libraries in an unsupported manner.
segment.target: Your app is linking C runtime libraries in an unsupported manner.

segment.source: The Microsoft C/C++ runtime library provides routines for programming for the Microsoft Windows operating system.
segment.target: The Microsoft C/C++ runtime library provides routines for programming for the Microsoft Windows operating system.

segment.source: These routines automate many common programming tasks that are not provided by the C and C++ languages.
segment.target: These routines automate many common programming tasks that are not provided by the C and C++ languages.

segment.source: If your app utilizes C/C++ runtime library, you need to ensure it is linked in a supported manner.
segment.target: If your app utilizes C/C++ runtime library, you need to ensure it is linked in a supported manner.

segment.source: Visual Studio 2015 supports both dynamic linking, to let your code use common DLL files, or static linking, to link the library directly into your code, to the current version of the CRT.
segment.target: Visual Studio 2015 supports both dynamic linking, to let your code use common DLL files, or static linking, to link the library directly into your code, to the current version of the CRT.

segment.source: If possible, we recommend your app use dynamic linking with VS 2015.
segment.target: If possible, we recommend your app use dynamic linking with VS 2015.

segment.source: Support in previous versions of Visual Studio varies.
segment.target: Support in previous versions of Visual Studio varies.

segment.source: See the following table for details:
segment.target: See the following table for details:

segment.source: Visual Studio version
segment.target: Visual Studio version

segment.source: Dynamic linking
segment.target: Dynamic linking

segment.source: Static linking
segment.target: Static linking

segment.source: Not supported
segment.target: Not supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Not supported
segment.target: Not supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Not supported
segment.target: Not supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Not supported
segment.target: Not supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Supported
segment.target: Supported

segment.source: Note: In all cases, you must link to the latest publically available CRT.
segment.target: Note: In all cases, you must link to the latest publically available CRT.

segment.source: Your app installs and loads assemblies from the Windows side-by-side folder.
segment.target: Your app installs and loads assemblies from the Windows side-by-side folder.

segment.source: For example, your app uses C runtimes libraries VC8 or VC9 and is dynamically linking them from Windows side-by-side folder, meaning your code is using the common DLL files from a shared folder.
segment.target: For example, your app uses C runtimes libraries VC8 or VC9 and is dynamically linking them from Windows side-by-side folder, meaning your code is using the common DLL files from a shared folder.

segment.source: This is not supported.
segment.target: This is not supported.

segment.source: You will need to statically link them by linking to the redistributable library files directly into your code.
segment.target: You will need to statically link them by linking to the redistributable library files directly into your code.

segment.target: In this section

segment.target: Shows how to run Desktop App Converter.

segment.source: You probably won't need to do much, if anything, to get your app ready for the conversion process.
segment.target: You probably won't need to do much, if anything, to get your app ready for the conversion process.

segment.target: Contains info to help you be successful deploying and debugging your app after converting it.

segment.target: Also, if you're curious about some of the internals of the Desktop Conversion extensions, this topic is for you.
